misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the computer uses human-readable output prompts (like 'Enter names:') as logical barriers that partition the input stream into distinct sections.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In reality, the Java Scanner class and the underlying System.in stream are independent of System.out. The computer does not 'wait' for a specific prompt to finish before allowing input to fill a buffer, nor does it know which tokens belong to which variable based on the prompt text. If a user enters 'Alice 85 Bob 92', the Scanner will read '85' into the names array (y) because it is the second token, regardless of the prompt 'Enter names:'.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program will fail with an InputMismatchException or incorrect data mapping if the user provides the input tokens in any sequence other than 'all names' followed by 'all scores', such as entering student data in name-score pairs.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that x.next() will read a full student name as a single semantic unit, even if that name contains spaces (e.g., 'Alice Smith').
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, the Scanner.next() method is delimiter-based, typically splitting input by whitespace. The student's mental model fails to account for the machine's strict adherence to tokenization; it treats a first and last name as two separate entries in the array, throwing off the parallel alignment with the scores array.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: If a user enters a name with a space, the 'names' array (y) will be filled with the first and last names as separate elements, and the program will crash with an InputMismatchException when it later expects integers for the scores array.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that x.next() will capture a complete 'name' as a single entity, regardless of whether that name contains a space (e.g., 'Alice Smith').
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Java Scanner notional machine treats all whitespace as delimiters by default when using next(). If a user inputs 'Alice Smith', the Scanner interprets this as two separate tokens. This causes 'Alice' to be stored as the first name and 'Smith' to be stored as the second name, leading to a InputMismatchException when the program eventually attempts to read an integer score but finds a string token instead.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the input 'n' (number of students) will always be at least 1, and thus the last element of the array will always exist at index n-1.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to account for the state of the notional machine when an array of size 0 is allocated. In Java, if n=0, the arrays are initialized with length 0, but any access to index n-1 (which becomes -1) results in an out-of-bounds error.
